p: Heavy rainfall is known to deplete agricultural yields, and food insecurity is associated with an increase in sexual risk through transactional sex and the inability to broker safe sex.32,33,34 Therefore, one possible explanatory pathway for our findings is food insecurity leading to transactional sex and other economically motivated relationships as a means of paying for food, resulting in HIV infection.35,36 This theory is supported by the finding that the odds of increased HIV prevalence with heavy rainfall were greater in rural settings, where people are more likely to grow their own food and be directly reliant on crop yields. In addition, flooding and food insecurity may be associated with migration, leading to the expansion of sexual networks and creating conditions conducive to intravenous drug use or exposure to gender-based violence.2 Another possible mechanistic pathway for our findings is that flooding or excessive rains can block access to clinics or cause damage to public health infrastructure, weakening access to health resources such as pre-exposure prophylaxis and HIV testing, education, and treatment. This hypothesized pathway is speculative, however, given that there are no published findings to our knowledge.
